<html><body><div><div class="content-body"><p>Australian politicians urged restraint on Tuesday after police in <a href="https://www.independent.co.uk/topic/sydney" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank" data-ylk="slk:Sydney;elm:context_link;itc:0;sec:content-canvas" class="link rapid-noclick-resp">Sydney</a> clashed with people protesting against the visit of the <a href="https://www.independent.co.uk/news/sydney-australia-israel-jews-melbourne-b2916475.html" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank" data-ylk="slk:Israeli president Isaac Herzog;elm:context_link;itc:0;sec:content-canvas" class="link rapid-noclick-resp">Israeli president Isaac Herzog</a>, who is accused of inciting a genocide against Palestinians in <a href="https://www.independent.co.uk/topic/gaza" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank" data-ylk="slk:Gaza;elm:context_link;itc:0;sec:content-canvas" class="link rapid-noclick-resp">Gaza</a>.</p><p>Police made at least 27 arrests amid allegations of excessive force used against protesters and rights groups, reports said. Violence broke out on the evening of 9 February after thousands of people gathered near <a href="https://www.independent.co.uk/topic/sydney" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank" data-ylk="slk:Sydney;elm:context_link;itc:0;sec:content-canvas" class="link rapid-noclick-resp">Sydney</a> Town Hall to oppose Mr Herzog’s visit.</p><p>The <a href="https://www.independent.co.uk/topic/new-south-wales-police" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank" data-ylk="slk:New South Wales Police;elm:context_link;itc:0;sec:content-canvas" class="link rapid-noclick-resp">New South Wales Police</a> said officers moved to clear the area after demonstrators attempted to breach blockades, resulting in arrests. Ten people were accused of assaulting police officers.</p><p>Tear gas and pepper spray were used to disperse the crowd, while television footage showed officers pushing protesters back and restraining some of them on the ground. Police said there were no reports of serious injuries.</p><p>Prime minister <a href="https://www.independent.co.uk/topic/anthony-albanese" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank" data-ylk="slk:Anthony Albanese;elm:context_link;itc:0;sec:content-canvas" class="link rapid-noclick-resp">Anthony Albanese</a> said he was “devastated” by the scenes and called for peaceful protests.</p><p>“Australians want two things. They don’t want conflict brought here. They want the killing to stop, whether it’s Israelis or Palestinians, but they do not want conflict brought here,” he told radio station Triple M.</p><p>“The causes are not advanced by these sorts of scenes – they are undermined.”</p><figure class="content-figure flex justify-center mb-[1em] mx-auto"><div><figcaption class="fig-caption"><p>A protester receives assistance after being pepper-sprayed by police (Getty)</p></figcaption></div></figure><p>The protests came as Mr Herzog began a four-day state visit focused on commemorating <a href="https://www.aol.co.uk/news/blood-bodies-everywhere-eyewitnesses-recount-182504531.html" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank" data-ylk="slk:victims of a December attack at a Jewish festival;elm:context_link;itc:0;sec:content-canvas" class="link rapid-noclick-resp">victims of a December attack at a Jewish festival</a> at <a href="https://www.independent.co.uk/topic/bondi-beach" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank" data-ylk="slk:Bondi Beach;elm:context_link;itc:0;sec:content-canvas" class="link rapid-noclick-resp">Bondi Beach</a>, where <a href="https://www.aol.co.uk/news/bondi-beach-suspect-charged-15-064832046.html" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank" data-ylk="slk:15 people were killed;elm:context_link;itc:0;sec:content-canvas" class="link rapid-noclick-resp">15 people were killed </a>in what authorities described as <a href="https://www.independent.co.uk/topic/australia" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank" data-ylk="slk:Australia;elm:context_link;itc:0;sec:content-canvas" class="link rapid-noclick-resp">Australia</a>’s worst mass shooting in 29 years.</p><p>He laid a wreath and two stones brought from Jerusalem at Bondi Pavilion and met survivors and families of those killed. “When one Jew is hurt, all Jews feel their pain,” he said, adding he was there to “embrace and console the bereaved families”.</p><p>“We were<a href="https://www.independent.co.uk/voices/bondi-australia-terrorism-beach-shooting-sydney-b2884195.html" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank" data-ylk="slk:shaken to our core;elm:context_link;itc:0;sec:content-canvas" class="link rapid-noclick-resp"> shaken to our core</a> when we first heard about<a href="https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/cricket/michael-vaughan-bondi-shooting-australia-ashes-b2884497.html" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank" data-ylk="slk:the Bondi Beach attack;elm:context_link;itc:0;sec:content-canvas" class="link rapid-noclick-resp"> the Bondi Beach attack</a>. Our heart missed a beat, like all Israelis and all Jews. And I’m here to express solidarity, friendship, and love,” Mr Herzog said.</p><p>“And I also believe that this is an opportunity to upgrade the relations between <a href="https://www.independent.co.uk/topic/israel" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank" data-ylk="slk:Israel;elm:context_link;itc:0;sec:content-canvas" class="link rapid-noclick-resp">Israel</a> and <a href="https://www.independent.co.uk/topic/australia" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank" data-ylk="slk:Australia;elm:context_link;itc:0;sec:content-canvas" class="link rapid-noclick-resp">Australia</a> because we are two democracies that share values together and we are confronting the roots of evil from all over the world. And we should do so together,” he added.</p><p>He said the stones would remain as a reminder that people of all faiths and nations “will continue to hold strong in the face of terror, violence and hatred, and that we shall overcome this evil together”.</p><figure class="content-figure flex justify-center mb-[1em] mx-auto"><div><figcaption class="fig-caption"><p>Police surround protesters on George Street, Sydney, on Monday (Getty)</p></figcaption></div></figure><p>Security was tight during the visit, with police snipers visible on rooftops. Mr Herzog is also due to visit <a href="https://www.independent.co.uk/topic/melbourne" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank" data-ylk="slk:Melbourne;elm:context_link;itc:0;sec:content-canvas" class="link rapid-noclick-resp">Melbourne</a> and Canberra before returning to <a href="https://www.independent.co.uk/topic/israel" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank" data-ylk="slk:Israel;elm:context_link;itc:0;sec:content-canvas" class="link rapid-noclick-resp">Israel</a> on Thursday.</p><p>Authorities had granted police rarely used powers during the <a href="https://www.independent.co.uk/topic/sydney" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank" data-ylk="slk:Sydney;elm:context_link;itc:0;sec:content-canvas" class="link rapid-noclick-resp">Sydney</a> protest, including directing crowds to move, restricting access to areas and searching vehicles.</p><p>A legal challenge by the <a href="https://www.independent.co.uk/topic/palestine" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank" data-ylk="slk:Palestine;elm:context_link;itc:0;sec:content-canvas" class="link rapid-noclick-resp">Palestine</a> Action Group against those restrictions was dismissed by a Sydney court on 9 February, preventing them from marching from the Town Hall to the New South Wales parliament. Mr Herzog was not present at the protest site.</p><p>New South Wales premier Chris Minns defended police actions, saying officers were required to make rapid decisions in tense and volatile circumstances. “I understand there’s criticisms of <a href="https://www.independent.co.uk/topic/new-south-wales-police" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank" data-ylk="slk:New South Wales Police;elm:context_link;itc:0;sec:content-canvas" class="link rapid-noclick-resp">New South Wales Police</a>, I just want to make it clear they were caught in an impossible situation,” he said.</p><figure class="content-figure flex justify-center mb-[1em] mx-auto"><div><figcaption class="fig-caption"><p>Herzog meets with students during a visit to Moriah War Memorial College on Tuesday (Getty)</p></figcaption></div></figure><p>Police commissioner Mal Lanyon said officers had shown restraint.</p><p>“Police did what they needed to do, which was to hold the line and then form and move the protesters back with a view to dispersing them,” he said. “Having an angry and violent mob marching on police is not a situation that I want our officers in.”</p><p>Protest organisers and participants disputed that account. <a href="https://www.independent.co.uk/topic/palestine" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank" data-ylk="slk:Palestine;elm:context_link;itc:0;sec:content-canvas" class="link rapid-noclick-resp">Palestine</a> Action Group Sydney said demonstrators were surrounded and unable to leave.</p><p>“The police began charging the crowd with horses, indiscriminately pepper-spraying the crowd, punching and arresting people,” the group said.</p><p>Abigail Boyd, an opposition Green lawmaker in the state parliament, said she had been punched by officers while attempting to vacate the site.</p><p>“I have a very sore arm and shoulder where they punched me. I’m really in shock,” she told a press conference.</p><figure class="content-figure flex justify-center mb-[1em] mx-auto"><div><figcaption class="fig-caption"><p>Many protesters have accused Herzog of committing war crimes in Gaza (Getty)</p></figcaption></div></figure><p>Protests were also held in <a href="https://www.independent.co.uk/topic/melbourne" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank" data-ylk="slk:Melbourne;elm:context_link;itc:0;sec:content-canvas" class="link rapid-noclick-resp">Melbourne</a>, where police said 5,000 people gathered outside downtown Flinders Street Railway Station, then marched several blocks to the State Library, blocking evening peak-hour traffic. A 20-year-old woman was arrested after allegedly burning flags and damaging a tram stop.</p><p>The visit has drawn mixed reactions within <a href="https://www.independent.co.uk/topic/australia" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank" data-ylk="slk:Australia;elm:context_link;itc:0;sec:content-canvas" class="link rapid-noclick-resp">Australia</a>’s Jewish community. Mainstream Jewish organisations welcomed Mr Herzog’s presence, while the Jewish Council of <a href="https://www.independent.co.uk/topic/australia" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank" data-ylk="slk:Australia;elm:context_link;itc:0;sec:content-canvas" class="link rapid-noclick-resp">Australia</a> published open letters and newspaper advertisements signed by hundreds of Australian Jews stating: “Herzog does not speak for us and is NOT WELCOME HERE.”</p><p>“We refuse to let our collective grief be used to legitimise a leader whose rhetoric has been part of inciting a genocide against Palestinians in <a href="https://www.independent.co.uk/topic/gaza" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank" data-ylk="slk:Gaza;elm:context_link;itc:0;sec:content-canvas" class="link rapid-noclick-resp">Gaza</a> and has contributed to the illegal annexation of the West Bank,” said the council’s executive officer, Sarah Schwartz.</p><p>Mr Herzog rejected accusations that he had incited a genocide and said protests against him sought to “undermine and delegitimise” <a href="https://www.independent.co.uk/topic/israel" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank" data-ylk="slk:Israel;elm:context_link;itc:0;sec:content-canvas" class="link rapid-noclick-resp">Israel</a>’s right to exist. Jewish leaders initiated the invitation extended by governor general Sam Mostyn at Mr Albanese’s request.</p><figure class="content-figure flex justify-center mb-[1em] mx-auto"><div><figcaption class="fig-caption"><p>Isaac Herzog’s four-day trip aims to console Australia's Jewish community after the Bondi Beach attacks last year (AFP/Getty)</p></figcaption></div></figure><p>The Australian prime minister and his Israeli counterpart <a href="https://www.independent.co.uk/topic/benjamin-netanyahu" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank" data-ylk="slk:Benjamin Netanyahu;elm:context_link;itc:0;sec:content-canvas" class="link rapid-noclick-resp">Benjamin Netanyahu</a> have been<a href="https://www.aol.co.uk/news/australia-albanese-says-israeli-pm-054548374.html" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank" data-ylk="slk:openly hostile toward each other;elm:context_link;itc:0;sec:content-canvas" class="link rapid-noclick-resp"> openly hostile toward each other</a> since the Australian announced six months ago that his government <a href="https://www.aol.co.uk/news/australia-joins-france-britain-canada-054845839.html" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank" data-ylk="slk:would recognise a Palestinian state;elm:context_link;itc:0;sec:content-canvas" class="link rapid-noclick-resp">would recognise a Palestinian state</a>.</p><p>He welcomed what he described as “positive steps” by the Australian government to address antisemitism following the <a href="https://www.independent.co.uk/topic/bondi-beach" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank" data-ylk="slk:Bondi Beach;elm:context_link;itc:0;sec:content-canvas" class="link rapid-noclick-resp">Bondi Beach</a> attack, including new hate-speech legislation and the establishment of a royal commission to investigate antisemitism.</p><p>Amnesty International <a href="https://www.independent.co.uk/topic/australia" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank" data-ylk="slk:Australia;elm:context_link;itc:0;sec:content-canvas" class="link rapid-noclick-resp">Australia</a> condemned what it called the “unnecessary and disproportionate use of force” by police and called for an independent investigation.</p><p>“The right to protest is protected under international law. What we witnessed last night was a serious assault on those rights and a deeply troubling display of State-sanctioned violence,” said Mohamed Duar, the organisation’s Occupied Palestinian Territory spokesperson.</p><p>Police said further rallies were planned, including a demonstration outside police headquarters in Sydney on 10 February, as debate over the visit and the handling of protests continued.</p></div></div></body></html>
